WV4Mz__uA3gnU-YAbQibKQ.text: The best Spanish restaurant in Singapore by far! I highly recommend the chochinillo asada iberico aka baby pig. You have to order a day in advance for this dish, but it's well worth it. The skin is perfectly crispy and the meat juicy and succulent. Also tried the house and squid ink paella which were both absolutely delicious. Yes, it was indeed a feast! It's a quaint little spot with beautiful ambience so great for date nights! But it can get busy and reservations fill up fast, so just make sure you book in advance. I heard a new outlet opened in Boat Quay so will definitely drop by when Bukit Timah branch is fully booked. Highly recommended!!!

tUvApURj9zL_7jTe2QqQ4w.text: Yummy and authentic spanish food in a cute setting! Can't go wrong with any of the tapas. Good service too. Glad to know there are still places serving good food in Singapore!

6cy7PGzqTtNyYg5oviPHrg.text: Great food, quiet restaurant (so can manage a sensible conversation), very good service, all in all very good experience. Very pricy.... Had 7 of the tapas (3 people), all were very good. In particular the Gamabari was the best but all the rest were very good.

photos.caption: Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. Chorizo and Gambari
Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. Jamon Iberico
Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. Black mussels

hbZhqUhKWRCtuwWOSMlGrg.text: Tapas and brunch on Sunday. A license to eat as much as we want! =OTortilla de Patata con Alioli (Potato Omelette with Alioli) Albondigas (Meatballs in Tomato Sauce)Hamburguesas. Mini beef burgers, with a equally tiny fried quail egg that pleasantly oozes when you press the burger bun together! Churros con Chocolate. This is the 'star' of the show. Dough pastry fried, dusted with cinnamon sugar, warm chocolate and ice cream, almost ice milk with a hint of lemon. Service is attentive and thoughtful. When they delivered the churros dish with all the rest of the food, which I thought was a dessert, but realized was a brunch item, they promptly took it away when I asked for it to be served later. They then made fresh churros because the previous ones were no longer hot! Definitely worth more frequent visits.

photos.caption: Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. Tarta de chocolate with homemade ice cream
Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. Paella de la Casa. The house paella with black mussels, chicken, prawns and chorizo. Worth the price of admission!
Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. More Hamburguesas with quail egg! A fav brunch item. Share or have them all yourself

FinBKG64Qc39mHvyO63OlA.text: Summary: This is the most authentic home-style Spanish restaurant I've had so far in Singapore. Food is fantastic, while price is reasonable (for SG!). Interiors are Spanish-homely and cosy. *Pros* are that the food is fantastic, reminds me of my trips to Seville and Madrid! Tapas are reasonably priced (for SG) and good with the flavour, not too salty. The jamon (Spanish ham) platter with five different selections was simply amazing. The main dishes are also pretty well done. The best thing we had that night were the Paellas: House and Squid Ink; Rice was well done (and made with real Spanish rice I might say!) and absorbed with the juices of the accompanying meats and seafood, which I feel thoroughly brings out the best medley in flavours. The party table beside us ordered a whole suckling pig (!), which I understand needed a prior 24 hours advance reservation. Oh yes, they also have a great Spanish wine selection, which I understand the owner imports the various variety by himself.*Cons* are that this place is not easy to book during the weekends, and service staff seems limited so they are always busy. I like that the manager and the chef do try to engage with the patrons when they have the free time. Nonetheless, the restaurant brings out the great charm and authenticity of real Spanish food, and the interiors are cosy and homely. The price is also pretty reasonable too, for Singapore. Would definitely go back for more! Recommended: Tortilla (egg and potato omelette), Jamon (Spanish ham) platter, chorizos (spicy sausages), albondigas (meat balls), pulpo (marinated octopus), gambas (prawn in spicy garlic sauce), clams and mussels, asparagus and garlic mushrooms, house paella (I hear the seafood paella is great too!). Yes - we had a party of six so we ordered quite a bit. Next time will try the suckling pig and the escargots!

PWDaSTAl3JoQcynDhRDe6w.text: A restaurant is defined by good food, good service, and a good ambience.  Unfortunately, My Little Spanish Place missed the mark on all 3 counts.  The food lacked salt and this is the first time I have had Spanish food that was under seasoned.  The service is quick, but relatively mindless.  They won't check up on you or act particularly hospitable.  The service and ambience were a combined point for us.  We had a baby and no reservations and inquired about a free table on a Sunday afternoon.  Although there were at least 3 empty tables indoors, we were told that we couldn't possibly finish in 30 minutes so we couldn't sit inside.  We finished in 30 minutes and I noticed that there was at least still one or two empty tables inside 45 minutes after we sat down. The restaurant was half full and seemed like a neighborhood spot.  But I can't imagine returning for the food here.The foodAlbondingas or meatballs are tender and come in a tomato based both though they were a bit bland.  Tortilla espanola or spanish omelet was well cooked with a sprinkle of parsley.  It wasn't oily and cooked well though it lacked some punch.  The pan/bread plate was a joke since it was S$6 for a plate of bread, olive oil, and garlic aioli.  The harmburguesas or sliders had a nice cheesy taste, but also lacked salt.The manager was saved from a verbal lashing from me only because my husband held me back.  I think that we were told to sit outside because of our baby and had a bad feeling from the start, but we stayed.  Now I can safely say, the food itself wasn't worth a visit.  Save yourself a trip here if you are looking for warm service and savory Spanish food.

8DMDuhRJBN1mjPNSTLIMLw.text: A good place for dates and acting like Don Juan DeMarco.Okay, I've never been to Spain. I have Spanish friends... but I've never been there. So I can only review this place with my limited knowledge of Spanish culture. I have on hand movie references and my Singaporean palette. I'm not a big fan of paella but I must say, I enjoyed this one! It's not too oily and every mouthful was tasty to the end. I like Sangrias and the ones they served here were yummy... come to think of it... I might just go there for the Red Wine Sangria. It tastes very much like a festive drink. I had some form of custard for dessert but i forget what it was called... just have the restaurant reccomend one to you! Loved the ambience and decor of the place. It was nice and quiet and i felt like I was on holiday there. Maybe it's because I went on a weekday, it was not crowded. Might be safer to make a reservation.

photos.caption: Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. Cosy dining here.
Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. I like restaurants and shops that are on the ground level.

hbVjCcRm1x4hrKAFJRe0qA.text: This cosy little restaurant is homely and charming. In part credited to the gregarious familiar service. And that impressive jamon bar.We ate:1) Joselito Guijuelo Iberico Bellota ($25 for 25gram serving): cured for a whopping 48 months, intense and decadent but so worth the cholesterol.2) Gambas al Ajillo ($16): fresh sweet shrimp sizzled with olive oil, fried garlic chips, and chilli pepper; that umami gravy was most sumptuous.3) Croquetas ($12): stuffed with jamon nubbins, cream, and mash; excellent on its own.4) Tortilla de Patata con Aioli ($10) - a thick, dense potato omelette layered with onions, and sided by aioli: passed muster, but was forgettable.5) Huevos Fritos con Chorizo y Patatas ($18) - fried eggs with chorizo and potatoes: What I expected was a breakfast hash of sorts, but this was really just a mish-mash of thick fried chips, fried chorizo dice, and a fried egg sunny side egg, strewn together. Rather disjointed and jarring

RoOWrYOyg49O_pxvuQ4iIQ.text: We went for Sunday brunch. Only a few options of Tapas available, but they were all delicious, especially the prawn, juicy and tender. The varieties of Spanish ham were very authentic, tasted super good, and very expensive too. =P The business was very good, so luckily we made reservation. Will definitely go back again.

x8dW7CQuMApIqjP1mJM23g.text: It's nearby.  It's reasonably priced.  The service is good.  The owner is involved, communicative and caring.  The menu is not on overwhelming War and Peace of every thing ever cooked and eaten in Spain.  What is on the menu is varied, interesting and very much of it's origins.We had appetizers a main and dessert.  In addition to the things mentioned above one of the hallmarks of a good restaurant - for me at least - is that I come away having encountered a new dish that made me want to make it myself.  That was the dessert.  I do not recall the name but it was basically a simple frozen lemon flavored meringue with sherry poured over it.  Wonderful.The charcuterie sausages were lovely and a healthy portion.  Good snails, nice artichoke hearts with ham - though a bit oily.  That may just be me as i don't recall a tapas bar where there wasn't at least on tapas that was oilier than I prefer.  The oliver was good though so it wasn't a major concern.Good stuff.  Restaurants like this deserve everyone's support.  If you live in Singapore, give it a shot.  If you're visiting and craving tapas, give it a try.Oh - and the 3 or 4 legs of jamon iberico that are given pride of place in the back of the restaurant taunt you like some porcine siren.   We didn't have any but will next time.  I am sure their call cannot be resisted more than once.

o8vgXMpZGwjoPSu3aIiNCg.text: This is a small cosy Spanish place ... The piglet is really yummy .. As well as the tapas and paella .. My friends and I had a great time catching up here

photos.caption: Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of My Little Spanish Place - Singapore, Singapore. Meatballs

z1RoByhTRmTefOIuJe-D1A.text: A cute little place with a nice atmosphere. We tried a few of the tapas and a salad and it was really good. I can not confirm the bad reviews about the service. The service staff was very nice and attentive. I would definitely recommend this place.

HsQCykHxbDnGO_EnRckTKA.text: My parents and I cannot possibly enjoy the food with the Extremely bad service by the two waitresses. So if we dress in shorts and slippers we get Bad attitude? The waitress threw the bill and walked off without waiting for us to even sign it. Oh, they never once smiled at us. When we called for them, they pretended to ignore us. When I went up to pass them the credit card, she said she saw me already. Looking away does not tell me you saw me.

21InZB0UrFNvFG3Ao4_YKA.text: In my opinion, this is my favourite place for seafood Paella and meatballs. I just love the atmosphere here and will be back with friends at least once when I am back home in Singapore this December.

TR2rq0TY-I-7qgNM-6gg-Q.text: Spanish food seems to be really expensive here in Singapore and this place is no exception. What's a Spanish meal without a paella and so I ordered their recommended paella with seafood and chorizo. The chorizo slices were really too salty for my liking and the seafood tasted a little overcooked. The rice was well flavored but way too dry as well. Then again please tell me how a good authentic paella should taste? The one authentic Spanish tapas dish I did enjoy how ever where the potato/cheese croquette. The potato/cheese stuffing was creamy and smooth , best of all this is a cheap tapas dish! And as always make sure you have a sangria to feel all SPANISH!
